description:
Cribrihabitans marinus is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Cribrihabitans marinus is typically found in marine environments, such as seawater and sediments.

The cells of Cribrihabitans marinus are rod-shaped and exhibit a cribrate (sieve-like) surface structure, which is a distinguishing feature of this species. This unique surface structure is thought to be involved in nutrient uptake and attachment to surfaces.

Cribrihabitans marinus is chemoheterotrophic, meaning it requires organic compounds as a source of carbon and energy for growth. It is capable of utilizing a variety of complex organic compounds, including polysaccharides, proteins, and lipids, which are commonly found in marine environments.

This bacterium is believed to play a role in the cycling of organic matter and nutrients in marine ecosystems, contributing to the overall functioning and dynamics of these environments.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Cribrihabitans marinus
